title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
library(dplyr)


Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

library(palmerpenguins)

penguins %>%
  mutate(
    long_flipper = case_when(
      species == "Adelie" & flipper_length_mm > 195 ~ TRUE,
      species == "Chinstrap" & flipper_length_mm > 200 ~ TRUE,
      species == "Gentoo" & flipper_length_mm > 225 ~ TRUE,
      TRUE ~ FALSE
    )
  ) %>%
  mutate(
    long_bill = case_when(
      species == "Adelie" & bill_length_mm > 42 ~ TRUE,
      species == "Chinstrap" & bill_length_mm > 52 ~ TRUE,
      species == "Gentoo" & bill_length_mm > 50 ~ TRUE,
      TRUE ~ FALSE
    )
  )

# A tibble: 344 × 10
   species island    bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g

title: Post With Code
text:
Experimenting with distilltools::icon_link in Quarto



In a code block puts them all on separate lines.


 slides


 materials


 video


But using inline chunks gets them on the same line (as long as there are no line breaks between them):
 slides  materials  video
also, note, need display: inline-block in the css

title: Post With Code

materials





materials 2

title: Post With Code

 materials

title: Post With Code
text:
Using btn and <i>

 materials

title: Post With Code
text:
Conclusion
Original strategy, <a> styled to look like button, is probably best (see this StackOverflow).
Also, use <i> rather than <svg> as that’s what Quarto seems to do (though note can style <svg> with CSS).
Also, using font-size CSS property makes both icon and text bigger with <i> tag, but not <svg>.

title: Syntax Highlighting in Quarto
text:
A while back, I wrote two extensive blog posts on designing and implementing a custom syntax highlighting theme for my website, written in {distill}. Now that I’ve rewritten my website using Quarto, this post is an update on that process for this format.


Quarto, like distill, uses a theme called arrow as its default. There are, however, some differences between the implementations for distill and Quarto. Firstly, when I applied my custom highlighting scheme, with its five-colour palette, to my Quarto site, I noticed an extra colour had slipped in.

title: Testing callout blocks
text:
See the documentation.






Note



Note that there are five types of callouts, including: note, warning, important, tip, and caution.








Warning



Don’t do that! simple appearance.








Important



Do do this!








Tip With Caption



This is an example of a callout with a caption.








Expand To Learn About Collapse





This is an example of a ‘folded’ caution callout that can be expanded by the user. You can use collapse="true" to collapse it by default or collapse="false" to make a collapsible callout that is expanded by default.









Don’t do that! simple appearance.









Don’t do that! minimal appearance.
